questions.neutral: Is the whole city running hot today?

hobby.message: I hear analog photography still survives in your hands.
Origami help keep the noise out?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: City’s restless, yes. Strange days.
Best to keep routines simple. Restoring old typewriters, for example.
Paper keeps its secrets. Not every key needs pressing.
The less said, the better, especially with everything that’s come out.
Everyone’s on edge since the archive was leaked.
I keep mostly to myself—restoring typewriters, small repairs, that sort of thing.
It's quiet work. Mechanical, dependable.
The noise outside hasn’t reached my desk… yet.
Old machines don’t care about missing neighbors.
Yes, it feels like pressure’s everywhere. Even the walls seem to listen these days.
I restore typewriters—a habit from before all this systemic meddling.
Spent hours fixing an Underwood yesterday while protests rattled the street.
Reading the news now makes every keystroke feel heavier, somehow.
It’s odd. I used to write more freely. Now I pause before I press a key.
Machines remember only what we give them—people, not always so.
It’s all tension out there, no? Even at home, nothing feels settled anymore.
I spend my time with antique typewriters—restoring, sometimes writing if quiet returns.
Yesterday, nearly scrapped a project. Some neighbor came back after years vanished.
Whole building was arguing about scores and rights. Hard to concentrate, honestly.
Funny—mechanical problems are reassuring. You know where you stand with a stuck ribbon.
Typebars don’t judge you, don’t track your mood.
What I type now, I lock away. Habit, maybe, or just caution.
Feels like the whole city’s unspooling at the seams these days.
You wouldn’t believe how loud words sound now, especially on an old typewriter.
Restoring them keeps me grounded. Before BCI, I used to fill journals every night.
Now, though, after that archive leaked, even typing feels risky.
Spent yesterday on repairs—fixed a stubborn carriage. Didn’t dare finish my page.
Neighbors stormed the hall, arguing about missing friends and old scores. Made me jumpy.
Strange, isn’t it? Machines faithfully keep our words, but we’ve learned to fear our own records.
When things settle, maybe I’ll write freely again. For now, everything just gets locked away.
hobby_answer: Still tinkering with old machines, mostly for the noise. Keeps me occupied.
Typewriters don’t go offline during blackouts, which is something nowadays.
Hard to find good ribbon, especially after all these disruptions.
Most talk in the building is about other things now.
Best to stay consistent with habits, I suppose.
Yes, still collecting. Mostly keep it to myself these days.
Picked up a non-electric Remington last month. Needed some work.
Blackout made it useful—at least I could keep notes when nothing else worked.
Lots of old faces coming back lately. Not everyone likes questions.
Harder to find parts now, after the archives went public.
Mostly just listen now, write less.
Yes, still collecting typewriters. Got an Underwood working again yesterday.
Something about the mechanics—feels genuine. Reliably analog.
Strange lately—housing doors opening, people returning after years.
When the BCI outage hit, these old machines were the only way to keep records.
Could hear everyone in the block panicking, but my study stayed quiet.
Even so, it changed how much I write—can’t help but look over my shoulder.
Still, a few pages each week keep me grounded.
Still restoring and collecting, yes. The old Olympia’s my favorite lately.
These days, after the BCI leak and all those archive stories, it feels different.
During the blackout, the typewriter was the only tool that never let me down.
Some neighbors saw me at it—suddenly, that made them cautious. Suspicious, even.
Ribbon’s hard to get, parts too, with the city so disrupted.
Some who came back started asking what I record. Makes the room colder.
Strange, using what I love to document an unraveling.
But I keep it up, even if I hide the pages now.
Absolutely—typewriters are all I’ve got from before it all changed.
Started in my twenties. Grew up thinking words on paper kept you safe.
During the BCI outage, I was the only one still keeping a journal by hand.
People don’t trust paper now either. Anything with memory worries them after these leaks and returns.
Neighbors ask why I bother—imagine, typing at night while all else goes dark.
One came to my door, wanting me to record his version of events—he thought that would protect him.
Sometimes, I worry about which stories to save or burn. Feels heavier now.
The archive showed us words aren’t always safe. Still, I can’t bring myself to stop writing.
I keep a briefcase with things I can’t risk leaving behind. Some things belong only on paper.
